citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There are 2 containers of medications on a cart in the kennel that are not suitable for use. A bottle of pyrantel pamoate
expired 05/2023. A container of Probios expired 10/26/2018. The licensee reports the container no longer holds Probios,
but rather another product, of which the name and expiration date are not transcribed onto the container. The product
appeared as a dark grey, clumpy powder. Expired or improperly labeled medications can be dangerous as the efficacy,
potency, and freshness cannot be confirmed. If the medications are no longer effective, normally preventable diseases
may become a problem. Correct by ensuring that all medications are properly labeled and not expired, so the licensee is
able to use the appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases. Corrected at the time of the
inspection.

The primary enclosure failed to contain an animal securely. A female Golden Retriever (Lisa #3596) escaped from her
outside enclosure during the inspection. She climbed up the front gate and squeezed herself between the top bar of the
gate and some loosened wire paneling. The dog was recovered almost immediately after escape, and she experienced
no harm. However, loose dogs are at an increased risk for injury or serious accidents such as being hit by a car,
consuming toxins, or other events which may lead to pain, distress, or even death. The licensee used Zip ties to fix the
enclosure. Correct by ensuring that primary enclosures be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound
and maintained so that they can contain the animals safely. Corrected at the time of the inspection.

Water was not available to two dogs at the time of the inspection. A male Golden Retriever (Mika #3794) and a female
Golden Retriever (Lisa #3596) had an empty bucket in their outside enclosure. The license said he forgot to fill it when he
was doing chores this morning. The dogs were both very active. When they were given fresh water to drink, they both
drank eagerly from the same bucket at the same time for at least 2 minutes. They both went back to the bucket several
times for additional water. Today’s ambient temperature at the time of inspection was approximately 82 degrees F. In hot
weather, dogs need water to regulate their body temperature by panting and drinking water. Without water they may
become dehydrated or can even experience heat stress and possible death. Correct by ensuring potable water is
continuously available to dogs. Corrected at the time of the inspection.

A female Pomeranian (Trixie #3313) and a female Golden Retriever (Ashley #9716) had heavy matted hair behind both
ears. Trixie also had a few mats along her topline. Matted hair can cause skin irritation or may be an indication of an
underlying skin or ear issue. A regular grooming schedule should be part of a preventative care program to ensure
healthy and unmatted hair coats. Corrected at the time of the inspection.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by September 15, 2023, or the applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License
Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There are 2 containers of medications on a cart in the kennel that are not suitable for use. A bottle of pyrantel pamoate 
expired 05/2023. A container of Probios expired 10/26/2018. The licensee reports the container no longer holds Probios, 
but rather another product, of which the name and expiration date are not transcribed onto the container. The product 
appeared as a dark grey, clumpy powder. Expired or improperly labeled medications can be dangerous as the efficacy, 
potency, and freshness cannot be confirmed. If the medications are no longer effective, normally preventable diseases 
may become a problem. Correct by ensuring that all medications are properly labeled and not expired, so the licensee is 
able to use the appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases. Corrected at the time of the 
inspection. 
3.6(a)(2)(iii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The primary enclosure failed to contain an animal securely. A female Golden Retriever (Lisa #3596) escaped from her 
outside enclosure during the inspection. She climbed up the front gate and squeezed herself between the top bar of the 
gate and some loosened wire paneling. The dog was recovered almost immediately after escape, and she experienced 
no harm. However, loose dogs are at an increased risk for injury or serious accidents such as being hit by a car, 
consuming toxins, or other events which may lead to pain, distress, or even death. The licensee used Zip ties to fix the 
enclosure. Correct by ensuring that primary enclosures be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound 
and maintained so that they can contain the animals safely. Corrected at the time of the inspection. 
3.10(a)  Direct
   
Watering 
Water was not available to two dogs at the time of the inspection. A male Golden Retriever (Mika #3794) and a female 
Golden Retriever (Lisa #3596) had an empty bucket in their outside enclosure. The license said he forgot to fill it when he 
was doing chores this morning. The dogs were both very active. When they were given fresh water to drink, they both 
drank eagerly from the same bucket at the same time for at least 2 minutes. They both went back to the bucket several 
times for additional water. Today’s ambient temperature at the time of inspection was approximately 82 degrees F. In hot 
weather, dogs need water to regulate their body temperature by panting and drinking water. Without water they may

become dehydrated or can even experience heat stress and possible death. Correct by ensuring potable water is 
continuously available to dogs. Corrected at the time of the inspection. 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
A female Pomeranian (Trixie #3313) and a female Golden Retriever (Ashley #9716) had heavy matted hair behind both 
ears. Trixie also had a few mats along her topline. Matted hair can cause skin irritation or may be an indication of an 
underlying skin or ear issue. A regular grooming schedule should be part of a preventative care program to ensure 
healthy and unmatted hair coats. Corrected at the time of the inspection. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by September 15, 2023, or the applicant will forfeit the 
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License 
Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
